[Erin DiBenedetto]: Hi, Erin DiBenedetto, 21 Dearborn street.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Uh, I live in the Hillside and the number of rats in the area has grown tremendously, especially this summer.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I personally called the health department less than a week ago and they're extremely helpful and very receptive.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I think accountability has to come in play.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I think people aren't taking care of the weeds in their lawns and they hibernate in the ground and they make holes in the ground.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So people think, and they live near food sources.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So gardens, fruit trees, those types of things, and they need water.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So they're gonna live near those things.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: My question is, if you do create this commission or whatever, would you go to different areas of the city and speak on this issue in a community way?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Like, go up to Hillside, gather the people there, go to the South Methodist Fire Station, have a meeting there, go to the community and educate them in that way.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It has to be hands-on, and if you really

[Erin DiBenedetto]: communicate to them, you're there in their area to help them and hear their concerns.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I think that going out to the community rather than just robo calls and on the online, and you really see the people that you are representing.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: face-to-face in that they see how much you care about this issue, they'll all work together.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: They'll talk about, I mean, I have no problem ratting someone else for not taking care of their property.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And that's how I feel because I am afraid of rodents.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And that owner, and if they're renting, I'm like, you're collecting the rent, pay someone to do it if you can't do it yourself.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: lower grades in teaching students to self-advocate at those grade levels, and maybe a unified sports program similar to the one that they have in Malden.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: But it's been a great committee.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: You can really work on issues and dig in on them and make a difference in children's lives.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Section eight, okay.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Group committee members who wish to place items on the agenda will provide written notice to the chairperson by Monday noon prior to the scheduled meeting or at the discretion of the chairperson based on extenuating circumstances.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I have a question.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Does a chairperson get to decline any item brought forward by a member to be put on the agenda?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Because that happened to me last year.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I wanted an item added to the agenda and the chairperson executed their right not to put it on the agenda.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And I would like that addressed in this policy.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I would like to see a change where the chairperson does not have the right to put a member's item on the agenda, only because as elected officials, we're here to voice for the community, and I think that a chairperson

[Erin DiBenedetto]: having that override really prevents you from doing your due diligence as a school committee member.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I am requesting that that be added to this.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: All right, well, I can just, I accept that that's the rule.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I also feel like it's a little bit of censorship as a, that one person from our committee gets to decide whether or not something is discussed on any given week.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So, I object to that, but I'm happy with moving forward with this at this point.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Yes.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: As you are aware, Medford Public Schools ended classes on Thursday, June 13th.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Do you want to go back to your?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Thank you for your work on this is this the same program as breakfast after the bell or is that a different program?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I know, I'm asking if you looked at both programs and made an informed decision between the two.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: No, I'm happy that you're presenting us with an option.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I just wanted to make sure that we were taking

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Every opportunity given to us when a private group approached a committee member with an opportunity to write the grants for us, for us to receive $10,000 per school to do a startup.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I just wanted to make sure we looked at that as well as this program and picked the right program that we can sustain long-term.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And if we're just picking one and not looking at all options, I want to make sure that all students are fed for indefinitely, not just a pilot program.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It's a non-profit programming that helps many school districts throughout the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to provide at no cost to them, and they don't gain anything.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It's a public service that they provide.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And they do it in the most needy of areas throughout the state of Massachusetts.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And they graciously offered to help MedFed write the grant, actually write them for us.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And I just want to make sure that we're looking at every option available to us so that we have the correct program that we can sustain throughout the whole state.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: The future of Medford Public Schools, I just want to feed hungry kids, but I want to do it in a way that it doesn't have to stop in December because it's costing us too much money.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I just want to make sure we do our due diligence and do it once, do it right, and make sure we did our homework.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It takes an average of three years to see any progress on an MCAS or a standardized test because it takes years of instruction for the students to learn the new vocabulary and move forward in those areas.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So even though we got our programming early and we're starting a little early with training, we'll see that in the next few years with science.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And we should see that growth among all subgroups because of that programming, because students have had it for consecutive years.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: you to work with the Medford district, what would be involved in that, what way you see us beginning, how you could walk us through some of the process, maybe come up with some ideas with our superintendent.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I don't know if there's any grants we can apply for, because this is a new initiative coming out from the state, and how we get expertise like yourself in helping our children in our classrooms.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I had a question.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Is it a funded mandate or an unfunded mandate?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Is there grants available?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Okay.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: You know, it's great to have mandates, but we as a committee or a school district have to find ways to fund these changes.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And if there's fundamental changes in how we need to teach reading and literacy to our early readers or early

[Erin DiBenedetto]: beginning people, I think that education is like a foundation of a house.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: If you catch it early and you have a strong foundation, you have a beautiful, strong house for many, many years.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And I always would love to do that, and I think this is worth investigating further for our district, and I would like to make a motion at this time through the mayor, to the superintendent,

[Erin DiBenedetto]: please investigate and give us some costs involved in bringing either a landmark program, Dr. Gobb, or something similar before us with this budget so that way we can move forward immediately and less families and children have to come before us pleading for help for their kids.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: and not early learners, so I'd like to make that motion at this time.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Yep.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Mr. Benedetto.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Thank you.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I have a few questions.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I would appreciate that.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And maybe even reach out to the landmark program and see what they can have to offer us.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I would like to do that as their kindergarten screenings happen, because we do screen them.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I don't want that type of assessment.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I want the assessment so we do it once and we know what the student need is.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I don't want it to have two steps.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So speaking on that piece isn't what I really, I don't think is the direction from what I've learned this evening as the future for us.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I just don't want to be redundant.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I don't want to answer questions that a teacher just gets an idea.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I want to know.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: But we're buying this right now.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: OK.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: My only point is with that, do we know that the cost difference between one of those eight programs and this program is significant?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: There'll be a traffic change.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Please advise your children to be more aware of cars in the neighborhood, as well as having our police force updated with that.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: First meeting for our community

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Evans from Lesley University, Lauren Carlin, ETL from the Andrews Public School.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Our committee had two focuses for this year.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: One is out-of-school time, and the second is disability awareness.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: At this meeting, we were focusing on out-of-school time planning and coordination for vacations and summer programs.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We started by describing our current programs, our before and after school program, our summer fun camp, and the city recreational program.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We discussed staffing and training for all staff and what types of accommodations are made for students with disabilities.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Before and after school program has a wait list and suggestions were made to work with Lesley University to try to fill

[Erin DiBenedetto]: some staffing needs so we can move that wait list along.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Also a great idea was to have CCSR and honor students from Medford High School to volunteer to help the program more often.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: The summer fund camp was discussed and the idea of an earlier registration for programs so we can meet the needs and numbers of the campers

[Erin DiBenedetto]: was also discussed.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Three-tiered pricing for early registration, regular registration, and late registration was offered.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: A handbook is being created for the staff, one for staff and one for families, so everybody has all the information necessary.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And it's clear how our summer fund clamp runs.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We have an EMT on staff, a nurse distributing medications, but training for the staff has been minimal.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We are working to increase that option.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: The camp does not ever turn anyone away.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: They do their best to accommodate all needs.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Even if a parent needs last minute registration, no child has ever been turned away from the camp.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Students with disability may qualify for ESL in order to maintain and not lose social emotional skills during the summer.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: IEPs of those students are shared with the camp administration by our special education department in early June.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: They're changing the registration form to encourage all participants' parents to provide IEPs and 504s for any student coming to the camp.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So we're able to

[Erin DiBenedetto]: prepare for every student's need and make accommodations when necessary.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Method Recreation is also present at the meeting and they have a staff member who has a long history of working with students with disabilities.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: They are open to attend any trainings offered.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It felt like it was a very productive meeting.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Many steps have been taken already to improve our programming and our communications with families.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: The meeting minutes have been attached to these notes as well.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Any questions, please let us know.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Thank you.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So this is really good data.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Even though a small variable or, you know, different kids or different classes or different people taking the test at different times, it gives us a broad area of which areas, like, which concepts in math we're stronger at and which ones we aren't.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: There is something that I came across with a parent

[Erin DiBenedetto]: recently that I'd like to see added, and that is a school nurse may not consult with the student's physician and get medication orders without parental permission.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Right.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Clarification is one thing.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Getting a different order from a doctor without a parent being notified is a major issue that I feel that this needs to be added, that parental permission for any, you know, changes.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Like a nurse is calling a pediatrician.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Getting a change in a child's medication order or

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And not notifying a parent is not appropriate.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And so therefore, I want to make sure parental notification is either given prior to that phone call or after that phone call that an order has been changed.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Because in this situation, the parent was never notified of the change from her child's physician to the school.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: No, I think it should be a policy on this document.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And I don't think it's a conversation privately.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It should never have happened to any parent to find out in a meeting in that it should be part of this policy.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And there is a motion on the floor.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Under Medication Orders, Parental Consent.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Yes.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Page one.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: A consent to administer medication, but not to call.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Yeah, to administer it.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: But this particular situation was

[Erin DiBenedetto]: the nurse called the doctor, the order was changed after that conversation and the parent was never notified that they called the doctor or that an order was changed and the parent got no notification.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I want that addressed in this policy since we're reviewing it.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I don't think that any parent would want the school nurse to change their child's orders with their doctor and not be notified.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Oh, it absolutely is, because we're talking about policy changes in this department at this meeting, and that's something that I had firsthand knowledge of happening, and it should be addressed in these policies.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Actually, I'm asking to amend the policy and add that a school nurse may not consult with the student's physician and get medication orders or changes without parental permission.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I also worry about the small group that's going to be left at the Andrews and what they'll be doing with their time.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Well, it's a weekend trip, but on that Friday, as long as they don't

[Erin DiBenedetto]: you know, is that community everybody's been reached out to to make sure that they're welcome to go on the trip?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Great.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: My other question is insurance.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I didn't see it listed here.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Insurance.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: As part of the fee involved.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We did have to cancel one of these trips at one point because of things going on in the world.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And as a committee, we voted to make sure that parents didn't lose money and the district helped out.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: But we made it so that way every trip from that point on had to cover insurance in case that were to happen.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So for cancellation, if the school committee decides that it's for any reason not safe to send our children to another state as that trip comes closer, that is covered, and the parents will receive all of their money back?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Yeah.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I know it might add to the ultimate cost of every child.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Right.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: But it is a policy to make sure that that is added to every trip, because we had to cancel at one point.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And it was a financial hardship for some parents to lose their deposits.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And the school system did step up in that occasion.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Do you need this approval tonight, or could you get us those answers before we approve this?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Or we can approve it and just make sure that that policy is adhered to.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: This field trip's been going on for years and years.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It's great for our students to get out in the environment and to do some science hands-on.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: of their financial situations, and I make a motion at this time to approve and move forward.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: There's a second by Ms.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And he said that throughout the community, they're struggling to bring in younger people into the trades and talented people.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We really need to communicate to people in the community the value of these jobs.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And these men and women make six figures.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I mean, they make a great living, and they provide well for their families.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And Medford was built on the backs of hardworking people from the trades.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We were shipbuilders in the beginning, and our commitment to our vocational school in the last few years has been exceptional.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I would really hate to see programming close, so it's appeal to people in the community that might hear this, and maybe to our newspaper to get out the word that Method really wants to offer strong programming to our students, and we need people in the community to step up and help us in any way they can, even if it's, I don't know, if it's

[Erin DiBenedetto]: current companies or graduates that graduated from the HVAC program at vocational school coming back to teach students.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And even if we have to offer some of those in the evening instead of the day, I mean, we might have to look outside the box to fill these needs.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And I really don't want to start outsourcing back to Minuteman.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We used to pay a million dollars a year in tuition to Minuteman, and then we were left with no money to invest

[Erin DiBenedetto]: of vocational programming, and we've come so far to offering great programming and great education to all of our students.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So this, to me, is almost an emergency situation, and we have to work as a team, and I will contact some friends in the industry and see if they can help in any way, and I suggest that all of us do that, and anyone listening that could offer any help to please call us.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: This is a great way for a lot of students to move forward in their career.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Children who, you know, college isn't the right choice for them or students that are gonna do both, trade in and college.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I mean, there are so many opportunities here and our community needs this.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So it's just a dire emergency.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: in any way we can as committee members.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I do have concerns with cutting maintenance and repairs at all.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: If anything, I would like to see more maintenance and more repairs as our buildings age.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Sometimes less if there's two kids in a car or a family of children, then it could be like 160 per child per day.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And I know we're getting new cameras in different areas, so we can do that.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And people not finding out important information online is, they feel insulted to find it out that way.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I'm really not sure what we voted for that night.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Yes, of course.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And the rumors that I'm hearing that he's telling people that he might be staying past June 30th, has anybody talked to him about doing any consulting beyond that point?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: No, this body has not talked about that.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Well, I would like to see the new superintendent make those choices.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: If that superintendent told us that they had flexibility in coming forward, I'm sure Mr. Belson can give

[Erin DiBenedetto]: the information, but the final decision, even restructuring of the central administration, you know, putting those positions back in place, I think that should be the new superintendent's place.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I don't think that a new superintendent should step in and, you know, have to work with what's been hired from an outgoing superintendent.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: His input can be done by June 30th, and then the new superintendent should have the final decision.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So, Mayor Burke, can I answer that question about the director of foreign language?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: For instance, so say the new superintendent wants our foreign languages to develop in a different road than we currently have in MEDFED.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Maybe a different language.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So say the new director of foreign language teaches

[Erin DiBenedetto]: a program that we might not be moving forward for for the next five years.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I would hate for that to happen when the new superintendent, like she talked about Mandarin in one of her interviews, I remember her.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: speaking about that.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So she might have a new direction and new programs in her mind of how to move MedFit forward.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And if we hire someone in a role that has what we currently have and what not our future is going to be, we could be tying our hands.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So that's why the importance of not hiring directors are important to me.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I really would like

[Erin DiBenedetto]: to either let her make those decisions on, you know, bring the finalists to her, maybe do the preliminary work, but really have some more input from the new superintendent and what her vision for our school district is gonna be rather than the outgoing superintendent, and someone have to work within those restraints.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So what happens is that you need a team of teachers that are able to respond to an emergency situation so you can be called away.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And a gym teacher or a physical education teacher or other specialists are usually on that team because they have the most flexibility in their schedule and can respond very quickly to different situations.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Whereas a classroom teacher might have at any given time 20 students in their care and not be able to respond easily.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I call them classroom teachers because they do teach classes of children, but they just have a little bit more flexibility about being around the building.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Mr. Benedetto.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Thank you.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I actually requested the meeting.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I requested the meeting because May 1st was coming.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: and my understanding that Mr. Belson was retiring as of April 30th, and that we needed to have an official person named as acting superintendent to get us through the transition.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I had no idea that there were other options at play that were gonna be presented that evening, so I too was shocked that this came up at this meeting,

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I assumed the vote of the committee, and when the committee voted to extend him to April 30th, I took on that, as that's my new role, is to support him till that point, and then make sure our district has somebody at the helm.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I really pushed to have this meeting.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So it was a little quicker than some, and it was a special meeting to discuss it.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: My understanding, that is,

[Erin DiBenedetto]: someone within the district would step into that role, whether a deputy, a principal, someone we felt confident, you know, to help us through, because Mr. Belson was also going to be present.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And knowing him, as we all do, we know he works way beyond the hours required, and he was being contracted to continue for 25 hours.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So he was accessible to help with any bigger issues, and I'm sure

[Erin DiBenedetto]: with his dedication to this community over all these years that he would wholeheartedly do that.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I honestly was shocked by the outcome of that meeting.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It didn't even enter my mind as a possibility.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Had I thought that that was a possibility, I would have, like I do usually, hey, important things are being discussed and put it on social media, please come.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: right, please come, or I would have requested that the meeting be televised, because I have done that also in the past.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And I know we're getting new cameras in different areas, so we can do that.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Because transparency is extremely important.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And people not finding out important information online is, they feel insulted to find it out that way.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I don't know what to say about the outcome of the meeting, but I can own that I did bring it forward and did not tell a push for it to be because I thought it was just an interest, you know, an interim person stepping in for two months.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Thank you so much, Mayburg.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I still have some questions, so I need some transparency and clarity on what exactly the superintendent's role is for the rest of this year.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Will he be, will he have whole power as the superintendent?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Will he be hiring and moving people from, and promoting people and providing raises?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And I also heard a few rumors that he's telling people that he's going to be here beyond June 30th.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Is that a possibility?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Is there something about that happening?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I just want to put it all out here while we're on camera and everybody's in the room.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I just have these general questions and if someone could answer them for me and any other questions that come up.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I just want to know are the rules we put in place in February for him to continue to April 30th still in place?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: or have they been removed?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I'm really not sure what we voted for that night.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So he cannot hire people or move people or give raises or promotions unless it's like something to just provide services till June 30th.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Anything beyond that, our new superintendent would be making those choices, like department heads and all of that.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Yes, of course.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And the rumors that I'm hearing that he's telling people that he might be staying past June 30th, has anybody talked to him about doing any consulting beyond that point?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: No, this body has not talked about that.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Well, I would like to see the new superintendent make those choices.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: If that superintendent told us that they had flexibility in coming forward, I'm sure Mr. Belson can give

[Erin DiBenedetto]: the information, but the final decision, even restructuring of the central administration, you know, putting those positions back in place, I think that should be the new superintendent's place.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I don't think that a new superintendent should step in and, you know, have to work with what's been hired from an outgoing superintendent.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: His input can be done by June 30th, and then the new superintendent should have the final decision.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So, Mayor Burke, can I answer that question about the director of foreign language?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: For instance, so say the new superintendent wants our foreign languages to develop in a different road than we currently have in MEDFED.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Maybe a different language.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So say the new director of foreign language teaches

[Erin DiBenedetto]: a program that we might not be moving forward for for the next five years.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: and a gym teacher or a physical education teacher or other specialists are usually on that team because they have the most flexibility in their schedule and can respond very quickly to different situations, whereas a classroom teacher might have at any given time 20 students in their care and not be able to respond easily.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And I took the salary for that week, multiplied it by 26, which would be the annual income, because I didn't get the year-to-date column.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I just, and I clarified that with you.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So there were two things that really stood out to me while we were getting information.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And it was pretty much from the audience members.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: The first was a middle school parent who said that their child came home and told her that another student was vaping in our schools, in middle school.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So that was alarming to me.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And I appreciated her candor in saying that there.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: The other thing that stood out tremendously is another student that spoke up during the meeting and asked for data to support what we were saying to her because she wasn't just going to believe that we thought it was bad for her.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: She wanted data and backup to support that.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And that's, we have bright children and we need to be prepared with actual facts and figures if we're going to tell them they shouldn't or shouldn't do with something.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I was impressed.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: at that as well.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: What I'd like to see, and I talked to you a little bit about this at the end of the evening, is really a hard line, a very hard line that we don't allow cigarette smoking in our schools or anywhere near them.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We're not going to allow vaping either.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We're going to have it in our handbooks.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: They're going to be at our submaster, I don't know if they're still submaster nights, our welcoming nights.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Our parents should know our routine.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It should be initialed.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It should be

[Erin DiBenedetto]: For a student that is vaping, we should show everybody, see, we're not doing this in MedFed.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: There are so many health things.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So vaping, you think you're just sucking in water.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It's not.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It's all chemicals.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And those chemicals are going into our children's lungs.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And they think that this is a better choice than smoking, which is even more alarming.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Because we don't know what it's doing in those lungs.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Because there could be 40 different chemicals going into your children's lungs.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It's huge.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It's very important.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And everybody's cool doing it.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And, you know, the way they hide it and the way they can use it.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And teachers, it can be happening right in front of them.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And teachers are supposed to be teaching, you know.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: You can't expect this from everyone.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So it has to come from the top, the sides, and the bottom up.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It has to be a whole community effort.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: to do this.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I was happy to see Penny from Team Medford, the whole group there.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It was a great program.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I wish it had been better attended.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: But if they're not coming to us, then we're going to go every athletic meeting that someone goes to, it should be presented and every coach should be trained on it.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I just think overall, it's going to be a bigger, bigger picture than we ever anticipated.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And having a school lunch person say to you when you're in the line and your friend's next to you, I'm sorry, you've already charged two over.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And someone hears it, it's an issue.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It's just an issue for me.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I'm not really on board with it as it's written.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And again, I wanted to go back to the report I requested on December 4.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: with how many free and reduced lunch applications we received by building, by school.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Are we getting the word out to everybody initially in September?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I know it's a great undertaking, so I was just still hoping to get that report before we make changes to what we're already doing.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I don't I don't know.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I'm still on the fence.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Is there a cost difference between the cheese sandwich meal and the other meal that the school system is paying more for one than the other?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Yes, there is.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: OK.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: My second question is, can we pass this without changing the food we offer to the children, without substituting the meal?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: contacting parents after three missed days, reaching out to do all the outsourcing, contacting them to get payment without saying, now you have this separate mail.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I'm making a motion at this point that you go back and you look at the guidelines to see if we can accept this without changing the actual lunch that the students get.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And if so, great, and if not,

[Erin DiBenedetto]: how much leeway we have in the number of meals that we need to, a minimum number that, or the largest number we can put down.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So the motion's on the floor right now for her to check the wording to see if we can do this and move forward without changing the lunches for any of the students.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I need a second.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I second.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: To see if we can meet the federal requirements without changing the mail options for our students.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Hello, I'm Erin DiBenedetto and I'm running for re-election to the Method School Committee.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: My goal as a committee member is to be a leader who has the experience and the relationships to deliver a solid innovation for Method.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Having served three terms on the Method School Committee, I'm bringing my record of fighting for residents and community organizing to our city.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: As a school committee member, I commit to work to make sure everyone in our district has the opportunity to succeed.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I promise to be that honest voice of reason for all our Medford children.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: My husband Joe and I moved to Medford in 1987 and raised our two children, both of which graduated from Medford High School.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Joey is a graduate of Worcester State University and is getting his master's degree in public health

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And my Caitlin, she's a graduate of Tufts University and is getting her degree as a nurse practitioner.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: My job as a special education coordinator for Prospect Hill Academy, where I advocate for children, gives me a unique insight to improving our schools.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I bring my knowledge of working in a school every day to our committee.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: In 2011, when my youngest graduated,

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I decided to run for Medford School Committee because my voice needed to be heard and because all children deserve the best education a city can offer.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Some of the things that have been accomplished while working with other members of the committee have been to ensure we have a balanced budget with any need for supplemental appropriations.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Our committee has creatively and resourcefully developed additional sources of revenue.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: The planning and implementation of technology upgrades and our new science labs at Medford High School are major accomplishments.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: These projects are not only offering the best education for our high school students, but they have increased programming for our vocational students.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: As a committee, we have reviewed new legislation regularly,

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Our committees have submitted medical emergency plans, concussion plans, and bullying plans to the state.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Upgrades have been made at our Curtis Tufts School, as well as our Kids' Corner for our youngest learners.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We have worked hard to keep our class size small.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We have purchased new ELA and math programs for our elementary schools, and there have been many, many more accomplishments.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: When involved in interviewing and hiring our new principals or evaluating our superintendent, we always try to be the voice of the parents and the students in our community.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: While we have done some amazing work, there is much more to do.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: As a committee, we need to ensure our students are prepared to compete globally for spots at our country's best universities.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We are responsible to make sure the programs offered to our children are supported with the material and the supplies needed for our students to have maximum access to the curriculum.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We need to preserve our traditional vocational programs while we keep pace with the changing needs in our workforce.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We need to analyze our testing scores and make sure we are meeting the needs of all our students

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So they all have every opportunity to excel.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We need to build online learning opportunities so all students have a way to access the curriculum and we meet all our children's needs.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We need to invest in our buildings to maintain them for the years to come while working to keep our students and staff safe.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We need to have open communication with administration, teachers, students, and parents.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: In the coming years, this committee may be involved in hiring a new superintendent of schools, which I think is going to be one of the most important roles our future committee will be undertaking.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I've learned from my many years of community involvement that some of the best ideas in government come from the neighborhoods, not the bureaucrats.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: That's why I'm asking you to reach out to me at 781-254-0095 with any ideas or concerns or ways that I can help you or your child.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: You're welcome.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Thank you.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I didn't hear that the teachers were upset until I saw the large group outside tonight.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: actually happy to see a lot of you because I haven't seen you in a few years because both my children graduated from the McGlynn Elementary and Middle School and then Medford High School.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So it was really nice to see you all and see you still dedicated and acting in such a group way, such a team building way to represent yourselves in such

[Erin DiBenedetto]: A difficult thing.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I'm very sorry to hear that you felt slighted.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: When my children were going into middle school, it was hoping that they would get into the McLean.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So, when I hear the difference now with the Andrews, you know, it's like we all say, it goes up and down at different sides.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: To hear that you're educating 60% of the high needs students in our district in middle school, that's a lot.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: 60% of your students in your school being high needs.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: That's a tremendous job that you're doing every day and you're representing

[Erin DiBenedetto]: in servicing children with very, very significant needs, and you're doing it really well, because if you weren't, I would have known that, right?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I would have known that and heard that, and that we would have had an issue.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We never hear of that.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: The only thing we do hear is our friends are going to a different school, and the emotional impact that has on people's children, and that breaks my heart,

[Erin DiBenedetto]: The social, emotional well-being of a child is so important to their education that we need to listen to how that's affecting people.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And all our intention was last week is to find ways to make the McGlynn, you know, their marketing, their PR, to let people know about the wonderful things and the wonderful teachers that you are.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: so that parents are aware of it.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It wasn't to say, well, the Andrews better, how are we gonna make the McGlenn better?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We know you're better.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We never even thought for a second that you weren't better.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So there's a lot of different combinations that could be.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So that's my other comment.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So them waiving accountability doesn't mean that we're not accountable as a district to make sure that our children were ready last year and that they're ready in the future.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I don't like when they dangle that carrot in front of your face and say, oh, well, it doesn't count this year, so don't worry.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It still counts to every parent and every child who took the test.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We as a community are not accountable for that.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We are still accountable for teaching our children how to take this test and how to do well on it.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And I don't want parents to think, oh, because it's not accountable by DESC that we aren't accountable as a committee and as an educational entity that to our students and to

[Erin DiBenedetto]: to have them do very well.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I just wanted to put that out there.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I don't like it when they say it doesn't count.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Because it counts, because the kids took the time to take the exam.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And you guys, as a school district, we spent a lot of time and a lot of money making sure that we do this well and do it right.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So it counts.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And it's the data.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: We'll use that data to set up for next year, so it does count to us in so many ways.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So that's just another comment, nothing directed at anybody here.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Are they considered enrolled?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Mayor Burke?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Mr. Benedetto?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Thank you.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I was able to come to the parent information night for the freshmen and juniors last week.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And this was announced that it was happening up at the high school and for a couple of reasons.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And I agree with the change in the program.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: First of all, you have hundreds of kids walking through the hallways at the same time, and they're going to have their phones out.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So you're grabbing one out of many that are doing it in the hallway.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So there's no consistency in trying to get them all to not use their phones.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Secondly, I feel like a lot of

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Our newer students, they keep their calendar, I mean, their schedule.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: They take a picture of their schedule.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And that's what they use so they're not going through the backpacks in the hallway and tripping other people trying to find their schedule.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Because they use their phone to get from, OK, which building am I going and what class am I in now?

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And they pull it up on their phone.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Children today use electronics much more readily than ever before, and that's how.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: They work everything, and there's people here tonight taking all notes of what's going on on their iPads, whereas I would probably have my pen and paper, which I did last week.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It's just a different generation, and we need to encourage them to use electronics.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: As far as passing in the hallways, it's not when you're going to the bathroom.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It's only when the bell rings and you have those three to five minutes to get from one class to another.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It's like you can't leave class and go out in the hallway and use your phone.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: That's when it will be enforced.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: That's the explanation that I got the other night.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So you need a carpenter and $6,000 in addition to the $200,000 that the superintendent is going to add to the light items.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Yeah.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Yeah.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Very good.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Thank you.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: Mr. Benedetto.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: I just wanted to touch base on what my colleague was talking about, because I do math health billing for the school I work at.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And that's actually for speech therapy, physical therapy, occupational therapy, that's

[Erin DiBenedetto]: That's refunding for those services that we provide students.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And instead of them going back to their doctor's office or outpatient visits, we do them in the schools.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And we have those people in the schools so that they can not only help the children that specifically need it, but they're in the schools so they help all children.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And when we don't receive those fundings, we're less likely to have funds to employ those type of people in our school systems.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And it does matter.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: So I don't think people realize it when you're just talking about funding being cut unless you tell them how it affects our children every day and the development and growth that people make early in their lives with OT, with speech, and the abundance of how quickly they learn and no longer need those services because they get them well.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And if you treat well and treat early is how I look at things, and then you don't have to treat later.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: You know, because you have the skills.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: You've mastered some of those skills, so you no longer need those services.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: But I just wanted it to be relatable.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It matters to our children.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: It matters not only in dollars to our city, but it matters to services among our children.

[Erin DiBenedetto]: And that's what we're here for.
